alert.note: Alert for Mono (California) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Warning issued May 22 at 1:39PM PDT until further notice by NWS Reno
info.description: ...Forecast flooding changed from Minor to Moderate severity for the following rivers in California...Nevada... West Walker River Near Little Walker and Coleville affecting Mono County. Walker River Near Mason at Snyder Lane affecting Lyon County. .Warm temperatures will continue snow melt in the Sierra. Heavy rain also fell over the weekend which has introduced additional water into the Walker River system. Combined with reservoir releases into the East Walker, the mainstem below the confluence will continue to rise through the week. Prolonged minor to moderate flooding is anticipated with additional rises likely with future warm periods. These may exceed this week`s crest. For the West Walker Above Topaz Lake...including Little Walker and Coleville...Moderate flooding is forecast. For the Mainstem Walker River...including Mason at Snyder Lane... Moderate flooding is forecast. ...FLOOD WARNING FOR SNOWMELT REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE... * WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast to continue. * WHERE...West Walker River Near Little Walker and Coleville. * WHEN...Until further notice. * IMPACTS...At 6.5 feet, Moderate flooding of lowlands, pastures and some rural roads from the West Walker River Canyon to Topaz Lake .including Walker Coleville and Topaz California. Similar to peak of June 2011, and slightly below the peak of June 2017. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 12:30 PM PDT Monday the stage was 5.9 feet. - Forecast...The river will oscillate in flood stage with a maximum value of 6.6 feet early Wednesday morning. The highest peaks will occur overnight. - Flood stage is 6.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 6.6 feet on 07/09/1995. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood && &&
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Even 6 inches of fast-moving flood water can knock you off your feet and a depth of 2 feet will float your car. Never try to walk, swim, or drive through such swift water. If you come upon flood waters, stop, turn around and go another way. Caution is urged when walking near riverbanks. Additional information is available at www.cnrfc.noaa.gov. The next statement will be issued Tuesday afternoon by 3 PM PDT.
